name: sugar
label: bad
reason: Excessive sugar intake is linked to obesity, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease.

name: high fructose corn syrup
label: bad
reason: High fructose corn syrup (HFCS) is a processed sweetener that has been associated with obesity, insulin resistance, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Excessive consumption contributes to metabolic syndrome and increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

name: passion fruit juice from passion fruit juice concentrate
label: good
reason: Juice concentrate retains many of the nutrients of whole juice, though it's more processed. Passion fruit juice concentrate still offers antioxidants and vitamins but should be consumed in moderation.

name: acidifier citic acid
label: neutral
reason: Citric acid is commonly used as a preservative and flavor enhancer. It is generally recognized as safe, though excessive intake may cause stomach upset in sensitive individuals.

name: acidifier citric acid
label: neutral
reason: Citric acid is commonly used as a preservative and flavor enhancer. It is generally recognized as safe, though excessive intake may cause stomach upset in sensitive individuals.

name: flavour
label: neutral
reason: Flavoring agents are used to enhance taste and may be natural or artificial. Without more detail, it is not possible to assess the health impact accurately.

name: maltodextrin
label: bad
reason: Highly processed carbohydrate that can spike blood sugar levels.

name: monoglycerides and diglycerides
label: neutral
reason: Monoglycerides and diglycerides are emulsifiers used to improve texture and extend shelf life in baked goods and margarine. While generally recognized as safe, they may contain trans fats, which have been linked to increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

name: sodium benzoate
label: bad
reason: Preservative that can form benzene, a carcinogen, in combination with vitamin C.

name: artificial flavors
label: bad
reason: Synthetic additives that may be linked to behavioral issues and allergies.

name: partially hydrogenated oils
label: bad
reason: Source of trans fats, which increase the risk of heart disease.

name: sodium chloride
label: neutral
reason: Sodium chloride, or table salt, is essential for maintaining fluid balance and nerve function. However, excessive intake is linked to hypertension and cardiovascular disease, especially in individuals who are salt-sensitive.

name: citric acid
label: neutral
reason: Naturally found in citrus fruits; used as a preservative or flavoring agent.

name: calcium propionate
label: neutral
reason: Calcium propionate is a food preservative used to inhibit mold and bacterial growth in baked goods. While considered safe by the FDA, some studies have noted potential behavioral effects in children, although findings are inconsistent. It is rapidly metabolized and generally exhibits low toxicity.

name: xanthan gum
label: neutral
reason: Used as a thickener and stabilizer; generally considered safe, but may cause digestive issues for some.

name: aspartame
label: bad
reason: Artificial sweetener linked to headaches and potential neurological concerns in sensitive individuals.

name: stevia
label: good
reason: Natural sweetener with no calories; may help with blood sugar control.

name: preservatives (BHA, BHT)
label: bad
reason: Butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) and butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) are synthetic antioxidants used to preserve fats and oils in processed foods. While deemed safe at low levels by regulatory bodies, BHA and BHT have been classified as possible carcinogens due to their ability to cause cancer in animal studies.

name: lemon juice concentrate
label: neutral
reason: Lemon juice concentrate is used as a flavoring agent and preservative in foods and beverages. Although it provides vitamin C, concentrated lemon juice can cause gastrointestinal discomfort in some individuals and may contribute to dental erosion due to its acidity.

name: lecithin
label: neutral
reason: Emulsifier typically derived from soy or sunflower; generally considered safe.

name: propyl gallate
label: bad
reason: Propyl gallate is an antioxidant used to preserve fats and oils in food products. It has been linked to potential genotoxicity and reproductive toxicity in animal studies, and long-term consumption may increase the risk of cancer in humans, although more research is needed to confirm these effects.

name: titanium dioxide
label: bad
reason: Titanium dioxide is a white pigment used to enhance the appearance of food products, particularly in candies and processed snacks. While generally recognized as safe, there are concerns about its potential carcinogenic effects when consumed in large quantities, especially in its nanoparticle form, which may be absorbed by the gastrointestinal tract.

name: sodium bicarbonate (baking soda)
label: neutral
reason: Sodium bicarbonate is used as a leavening agent in baking and as an acidity regulator. In small quantities, it is generally considered safe; however, excessive consumption can lead to an electrolyte imbalance, potentially causing metabolic alkalosis or other health issues.

name: guar gum
label: neutral
reason: Guar gum is a galactomannan polysaccharide derived from guar beans, used as a thickening and stabilizing agent. It has a high soluble fiber content, which can aid glycemic control and satiety. However, excessive consumption may cause gastrointestinal discomfort, and dry powder forms may pose a choking hazard if not properly hydrated (EFSA Journal, 2017).

name: methylcellulose
label: neutral
reason: Methylcellulose is a cellulose derivative used as a thickening agent, emulsifier, and stabilizer in processed foods. It is considered safe by regulatory agencies; however, in large amounts, it may cause digestive disturbances or an osmotic laxative effect.

name: caramel color
label: neutral
reason: Caramel color is a common food colorant made by heating sugar, often with acids or alkalis. Although considered safe for consumption, some types of caramel color, particularly those containing 4-methylimidazole (4-MEI), have been associated with cancer risk in animal studies, leading to regulatory scrutiny over its safety.

name: sodium citrate
label: neutral
reason: Sodium citrate is used as a buffering agent, preservative, and flavoring agent in processed foods and beverages. It is typically recognized as safe, though high levels of sodium intake from multiple sources could lead to sodium overload, potentially contributing to hypertension.

name: ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
label: good
reason: Ascorbic acid is a water-soluble vitamin with potent antioxidant properties that protect against oxidative stress and support immune function. It also plays a key role in collagen synthesis, contributing to healthy skin, blood vessels, and wound healing.

name: sorbitol
label: neutral
reason: Sorbitol is a sugar alcohol used as a low-calorie sweetener and humectant. It is slowly absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract and can cause osmotic diarrhea at higher doses. While considered safe for use by the FDA, excessive consumption may lead to bloating, gas, and laxative effects, particularly in individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

name: sucralose
label: bad
reason: Sucralose is a chlorinated artificial sweetener approximately 600 times sweeter than sucrose. While approved by global food safety authorities, emerging research indicates it may alter gut microbiota and glucose homeostasis. Heating sucralose at high temperatures can also generate potentially harmful chlorinated byproducts (Baireddy et al., 2019, *Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health*).

name: propylene glycol
label: neutral
reason: Propylene glycol is a synthetic organic compound used as a humectant, solvent, and preservative in food products. It is generally recognized as safe (GRAS) by the FDA, but high doses in animal studies have shown signs of renal and hepatic stress. In humans, it is metabolized to lactic acid, and toxicity is rare at permitted food levels (Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, 1997).

name: monosodium glutamate (MSG)
label: bad
reason: Monosodium glutamate is a flavor enhancer commonly added to processed foods. While it is generally considered safe, some individuals report symptoms such as headaches and sweating, often referred to as the 'Chinese restaurant syndrome.' There is also ongoing debate about its potential role in neurotoxic effects at high consumption levels.

name: yellow 5 (tartrazine)
label: bad
reason: Yellow 5 is a synthetic food dye that has been linked to allergic reactions, particularly in children. Some studies suggest that tartrazine may exacerbate hyperactivity or behavioral issues in children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), though the evidence is mixed.

name: beta-carotene
label: good
reason: Beta-carotene is a carotenoid with provitamin A activity, converted in the body into retinol. It acts as an antioxidant, protecting against oxidative damage. Dietary intake is associated with improved eye health and immune function, though excessive supplementation in smokers has been linked to increased lung cancer risk (ATBC Study, 1994, *New England Journal of Medicine*).

name: hydrolyzed vegetable protein
label: bad
reason: Hydrolyzed vegetable protein is a flavor enhancer derived from plant proteins, often used in soups, sauces, and processed snacks. It contains glutamic acid, which may trigger similar reactions as monosodium glutamate (MSG) in sensitive individuals, including headaches and flushing.

name: cornstarch
label: neutral
reason: Cornstarch is a carbohydrate derived from corn, commonly used as a thickening agent. While generally safe for most people, excessive intake can contribute to increased caloric intake and blood sugar spikes, especially in processed foods containing high amounts of refined starch.

name: butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA)
label: bad
reason: BHA is a synthetic antioxidant used to preserve fats and oils in food products. It has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) as possibly carcinogenic to humans, due to evidence of carcinogenicity in animal models, particularly in the development of forestomach tumors.

name: salt
label: neutral
reason: Essential in small amounts, but high consumption can raise blood pressure.

name: monosodium glutamate
label: neutral
reason: Generally recognized as safe, but may cause sensitivity in some individuals.

name: natural flavors
label: neutral
reason: Derived from natural sources but often processed; not necessarily healthy or unhealthy.

name: vitamin c
label: good
reason: Powerful antioxidant that supports immune function and skin health.

name: carboxymethylcellulose
label: bad
reason: Carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) is a synthetic cellulose derivative commonly used as an emulsifier and thickener in processed foods. Recent research suggests that chronic consumption of CMC may disrupt gut microbiota composition and increase intestinal inflammation, potentially contributing to metabolic dysregulation and inflammatory bowel conditions (Chassaing et al., 2015, *Nature*).

name: potassium sorbate
label: neutral
reason: Potassium sorbate is a salt of sorbic acid widely utilized as a food preservative due to its antifungal properties. It is generally recognized as safe (GRAS) by the FDA; however, in high concentrations or prolonged exposure, it may cause mild mucosal or dermal irritation, though current toxicological assessments indicate low systemic toxicity.

name: erythritol
label: good
reason: Erythritol is a naturally occurring sugar alcohol used as a non-nutritive sweetener. It is absorbed in the small intestine and excreted unchanged in the urine, resulting in negligible impact on blood glucose or insulin levels. Studies indicate that erythritol is generally well-tolerated, though excessive intake may induce gastrointestinal discomfort in sensitive individuals (Munro et al., 1998, *Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology*).

name: BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole)
label: bad
reason: Butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) is a synthetic antioxidant used to prevent lipid oxidation in fats and oils. While approved by regulatory agencies within specified limits, BHA has been classified as 'possibly carcinogenic to humans' (Group 2B) by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) due to evidence of forestomach tumors in rodent models (IARC Monographs, Vol. 40).

name: niacin (vitamin B3)
label: good
reason: Niacin, or vitamin B3, is a water-soluble vitamin essential for oxidative metabolism, functioning as a precursor to NAD⁺ and NADP⁺. It plays a critical role in DNA repair, cellular signaling, and lipid metabolism. Therapeutic doses have been used to manage dyslipidemia, though high intakes may cause transient cutaneous flushing and hepatotoxicity in rare cases (Institute of Medicine, 1998).

name: sodium nitrite
label: bad
reason: Sodium nitrite is a curing agent commonly used in processed meats to inhibit microbial growth and enhance color. While effective in preventing botulism, nitrites can react with amines in food to form nitrosamines, compounds classified as probable human carcinogens by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC Group 2A). Epidemiological studies have associated high intake with increased risk of colorectal cancer.

name: inositol
label: good
reason: Inositol is a carbohydrate compound structurally similar to glucose, involved in cellular signaling and membrane function. Supplementation has demonstrated efficacy in improving insulin sensitivity and mood regulation, particularly in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and anxiety disorders (Nestler et al., 1999, *New England Journal of Medicine*). It is considered safe and well-tolerated in therapeutic doses.

name: carrageenan
label: neutral
reason: Carrageenan is a sulfated polysaccharide extracted from red seaweed, used as a gelling and stabilizing agent in foods. While undegraded carrageenan is generally regarded as safe, some animal studies have raised concerns about gastrointestinal inflammation with degraded (low molecular weight) forms. Regulatory bodies differentiate between food-grade and degraded carrageenan, but controversy persists regarding its long-term safety.

name: tocopherol (vitamin E)
label: good
reason: Tocopherol refers to a group of fat-soluble compounds with antioxidant properties that protect cellular membranes from oxidative damage. Vitamin E plays a role in immune modulation and prevention of lipid peroxidation. Deficiency can lead to neuromuscular issues, while excess supplementation has shown mixed results in chronic disease prevention (Traber & Atkinson, 2007, *Free Radical Biology and Medicine*).

name: fiber
label: good
reason: Helps regulate digestion and supports a healthy gut microbiome.

name: riboflavin (vitamin B2)
label: good
reason: Riboflavin is a water-soluble vitamin involved in energy metabolism and redox reactions as part of flavoproteins (FAD and FMN). Deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, presenting with sore throat, stomatitis, and skin disorders. It is essential for normal cellular function and growth.

name: lactic acid
label: neutral
reason: Lactic acid is a naturally occurring organic acid used as a preservative, acidity regulator, and flavoring agent. It is produced through fermentation and plays a role in food preservation. It is considered safe and is also produced endogenously in human metabolism.

name: sodium ascorbate
label: good
reason: Sodium ascorbate is a sodium salt of ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and functions as an antioxidant and preservative. It supports collagen synthesis and immune defense, and has been shown to reduce oxidative stress. Unlike ascorbic acid, it is less acidic, making it more suitable for individuals with gastrointestinal sensitivity.

name: pectin
label: good
reason: Pectin is a soluble dietary fiber derived from fruit cell walls, primarily used as a gelling agent. It has prebiotic properties, helps regulate blood glucose, and supports lipid metabolism. Clinical studies suggest that pectin supplementation can lower total and LDL cholesterol (EFSA Journal, 2010).

name: acetylated distarch phosphate
label: neutral
reason: A chemically modified starch used as a thickener and stabilizer, it resists digestion and may act as a resistant starch. Toxicological studies support its safety at typical intake levels, though long-term metabolic effects remain under investigation (EFSA, 2017).

name: glucose syrup
label: bad
reason: Glucose syrup is a concentrated solution of glucose derived from starch hydrolysis. It is rapidly absorbed, contributing to blood sugar spikes and insulin resistance. High consumption is associated with increased risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes.

name: canola oil
label: neutral
reason: Canola oil is low in saturated fat and contains omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids. While often considered heart-healthy, concerns have been raised about its processing (e.g., refinement and deodorization) and omega-6:omega-3 imbalance. Overall health impact depends on dietary context and intake.

name: BHT (butylated hydroxytoluene)
label: bad
reason: BHT is a synthetic antioxidant used to prevent rancidity in fats and oils. Although approved by regulatory bodies within specified limits, some animal studies suggest potential for carcinogenicity and endocrine disruption, prompting precautionary avoidance in certain consumer groups (IARC, Group 3).

name: alum (aluminum potassium sulfate)
label: bad
reason: Alum is used as a firming agent and pickling additive. Chronic exposure to aluminum compounds has raised concerns about neurotoxicity and potential links to Alzheimer’s disease, although conclusive human evidence is lacking. Regulatory agencies recommend limiting aluminum intake, especially in children.

name: choline
label: good
reason: Choline is an essential nutrient involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, lipid transport, and methylation pathways. Adequate intake supports brain development and liver function. Deficiency can lead to fatty liver and muscle damage (Zeisel & da Costa, 2009, *Annual Review of Nutrition*).

name: silicon dioxide
label: neutral
reason: Silicon dioxide (silica) is used as an anti-caking agent in powdered foods. It is considered inert and non-toxic at levels used in food, though nanoparticles of silica are under scrutiny for potential inflammatory effects. Regulatory authorities generally affirm its safety.

name: polydextrose
label: good
reason: Polydextrose is a synthetic polymer of glucose used as a low-calorie bulking agent and soluble fiber. It promotes satiety and has prebiotic effects, supporting gut health. Excessive consumption may cause mild gastrointestinal distress in sensitive individuals (Slavin, 2013, *Nutrition Research Reviews*).

name: yeast extract
label: neutral
reason: Yeast extract is a flavor enhancer rich in glutamates, B vitamins, and peptides. Though often misunderstood as a hidden form of MSG, it is naturally derived and generally considered safe. Allergic reactions are rare, though individuals sensitive to glutamates may choose to limit intake.

name: agar
label: good
reason: Agar is a polysaccharide obtained from red algae used as a vegan gelatin alternative. It has laxative properties and acts as a dietary fiber, aiding in bowel regulation and satiety. It is non-digestible and has demonstrated safety in human consumption.

name: phosphoric acid
label: bad
reason: Phosphoric acid is a common additive in carbonated beverages that imparts acidity. Excessive consumption has been linked to reduced bone mineral density and disruptions in calcium-phosphorus homeostasis, especially when intake of calcium is low (Tucker et al., 2006, *American Journal of Clinical Nutrition*).

name: retinol (vitamin A)
label: good
reason: Retinol is a fat-soluble vitamin essential for vision, immune function, and epithelial cell integrity. Deficiency can lead to night blindness and increased infection risk. Excessive intake, particularly in supplement form, may cause hepatotoxicity and teratogenic effects (WHO, 2009).

name: phytic acid
label: neutral
reason: Phytic acid is a naturally occurring compound in grains and legumes that chelates minerals such as iron, zinc, and calcium, reducing their bioavailability. While sometimes called an 'anti-nutrient,' it also exhibits antioxidant and potential anticancer properties (Lopez et al., 2002, *J Agric Food Chem*).

name: benzoic acid
label: neutral
reason: Benzoic acid is used as a food preservative for its antimicrobial properties. It is generally recognized as safe at regulated concentrations, though it may cause hypersensitivity in susceptible individuals and can form benzene when combined with vitamin C under certain conditions.

name: quercetin
label: good
reason: Quercetin is a polyphenolic flavonoid found in fruits and vegetables. It exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antihistamine effects and may reduce oxidative stress markers. Preliminary research supports its role in cardiovascular and immune health (Li et al., 2016, *Nutrients*).

name: polyphosphates
label: bad
reason: Polyphosphates are used in processed meats and seafood to retain moisture and improve texture. Excessive intake may disrupt mineral balance and negatively affect kidney function, especially in individuals with compromised renal health (Calvo & Uribarri, 2013, *Advances in Nutrition*).

name: cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12)
label: good
reason: Cyanocobalamin is a synthetic form of vitamin B12, crucial for neurological function, DNA synthesis, and red blood cell formation. Deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia and neurological impairment. It is especially important in vegan and elderly populations due to malabsorption risks.

name: acetylated distarch adipate
label: neutral
reason: Acetylated distarch adipate is a modified starch used as a thickener and stabilizer. It is resistant to digestion and often classified as resistant starch. Current toxicological data indicate low risk at permitted food use levels, with some interest in its prebiotic potential.

name: casein
label: neutral
reason: Casein is a slow-digesting milk protein often used in nutritional supplements. It provides essential amino acids and supports muscle protein synthesis, but may cause allergic reactions in individuals with dairy protein allergies or intolerance.

name: curcumin
label: good
reason: Curcumin is the bioactive polyphenol in turmeric, known for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. Studies suggest potential therapeutic benefits in metabolic syndrome, arthritis, and neurodegenerative conditions, though its poor bioavailability limits systemic impact without enhancers like piperine (Hewlings & Kalman, 2017, *Foods*).

name: glucono delta-lactone
label: neutral
reason: Glucono delta-lactone is a food additive used as a sequestrant, acidifier, and curing agent. It hydrolyzes into gluconic acid in water and is considered safe, with low toxicity and widespread use in tofu production and leavening systems.

name: iron
label: good
reason: Essential mineral that helps carry oxygen in the blood.

name: calcium
label: good
reason: Supports strong bones and teeth, and plays a role in muscle function.

name: preservatives
label: bad
reason: May include synthetic chemicals like BHA and BHT, which have potential health risks.

name: omega-3
label: good
reason: Essential fatty acids that reduce inflammation and support heart and brain health.

name: black beans
label: neutral
reason: Black beans is commonly used in commercial food products. It provides texture, flavor, or nutritional value, and is generally recognized as safe when consumed in normal dietary amounts. However, individual tolerances may vary depending on health status and preparation method.

name: kidney beans
label: neutral
reason: Kidney beans is commonly used in commercial food products. It provides texture, flavor, or nutritional value, and is generally recognized as safe when consumed in normal dietary amounts. However, individual tolerances may vary depending on health status and preparation method.

label: neutral
reason: Chickpeas is commonly used in commercial food products. It provides texture, flavor, or nutritional value, and is generally recognized as safe when consumed in normal dietary amounts. However, individual tolerances may vary depending on health status and preparation method.

label: neutral
reason: Lentils is commonly used in commercial food products. It provides texture, flavor, or nutritional value, and is generally recognized as safe when consumed in normal dietary amounts. However, individual tolerances may vary depending on health status and preparation method.
